item.title: Ticket #4577 (Update Incoming Links URI API (Technorati Feeds)) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Added patch to use Google Blogsearch instead of Technorati for Incoming Links feed, as per matt's suggestion.

Oh, this still gets a +1 from me too. :)

item.title: 4577-google-trunk.diff attached to Ticket #4577
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Patch for trunk to use Google instead of Technorati for Incoming Links display

item.title: Ticket #4051 (blogroll not functional for internal links) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Keywords, Priority, Severity changed

Attached a patch that will replace the clean_url call in _walk_bookmarks with a filter. Also added a default filter to hook that to clean_url. By itself, this patch changes nothing. However, it allows plugins to disable it entirely (my preference) or to just modify that filter and thus replace the $protocols parameter of the call to clean_url. Thus a plugin can add allowed protocols and such as well as simply disabling it. Allows for both choices.

item.title: 4051.diff attached to Ticket #4051
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Replace clean_url in _walk_bookmarks with a default filter.

item.title: flatimport-tuto.html attached to Ticket #4611
item.dc:creator: albaran
item.description: in-line tutorial

item.title: Ticket #4677 (Automatic REPAIR TABLE tablename after MySQL error 127) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
+1 as a plugin (if that's possible when the DB throws a 127?) -1 as part of the core.

Wordpress is a blogging tool, not a sysadmin tool and therefore (by default) shouldn't pretend to be one.

Also, the 127 error happened/happens for a reason. You should find out why instead of just fixing the symptoms by doing a REPAIR TABLE.

item.title: Ticket #4677 (Automatic REPAIR TABLE tablename after MySQL error 127) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
+1 sounds like a good idea.

Maybe a page like the upgrade page in the admin area which is shown on detection and allows the admin to run the repair.

item.title: Ticket #4677 (Automatic REPAIR TABLE tablename after MySQL error 127) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Whenever a MySQL error 127 crops up, the solution (for me) has always been to repair the table... and it always works. Should we detect these errors and attempt to repair automatically?

item.title: Ticket #4674 ("Weblog" is additional unnecessary terminology) updated
item.dc:creator: JeremyVisser
item.description: Oh, by the way, that list is from WP 2.2.1, but I'm sure it's more-or-less the same in trunk.

item.title: Ticket #4674 ("Weblog" is additional unnecessary terminology) updated
item.dc:creator: JeremyVisser
item.description:
Agreed. Weblog is an old term. The following files contain occurrences of the term 'weblog':

  • wp-admin/install.php
  • wp-admin/upgrade-schema.php
  • wp-admin/upgrade-functions.php
  • wp-admin/options-general.php
  • wp-content/themes/default/sidebar.php
  • wp-includes/comment.php
  • xmlrpc.php

item.title: Ticket #4671 (Empty ul in RSS widget when only a title present) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
Keywords, Version, Component, Milestone changed

2.3 has not yet been released, so I assume you're running 2.2.1, the latest stable release.

Patch looks good. 2 small suggestions though:

  • You're mixing print and echo. I'd prefer only echo as thats the standard throughout the codebase.
  • You could combine the exisiting is_array and new is_empty into a single if statement. This would result in a smaller and cleaner patch.

item.title: Ticket #4674 ("Weblog" is additional unnecessary terminology) created
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
"Weblog" is additional unnecessary terminology. It is used in quite a few places in wp-admin/ but is not the term used on ​http://wordpress.org/ . The term "blog" should be used throughout.

I will leave "Just another WordPress weblog" b/c that seems sacred ;-)

item.title: 4230.diff attached to Ticket #4230
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Makes update links functionality into a wp-cron job.

item.title: Ticket #4230 (Change update-links to be wp-cron compatible) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Keywords changed

Added patch to move update links into a cron job. Features of this patch:

  • Adds two new functions. One does the updating of the links, the other manages the wp-cron scheduling based on the enabling/disabling of the links update option.
  • Scheduling frequency is filtered for easy plugin changing (defaults to daily).
  • Both new functions are pluggable, in case a plugin wants to change how the updating or scheduling works entirely.

item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #4499 (Equality checks in query.php can break permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Looks good to me, mark. It may not fix all of the possibles of this issue, but it does fix the hour/minute/second ones.

item.title: Ticket #4604 (Feeds should be canonical) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #4604 (Feeds should be canonical) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Added patch to make all the root feed files do redirects to the correct URLs (as given by bloginfo() calls).

I still think the better course is to delete these files entirely from trunk. Let people fix their templates to not reference them at all. Still, if you really prefer to force 301's, this should work.

item.title: 4604-redirect.diff attached to Ticket #4604
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description: Makes the root feed files do 301 redirects.

item.title: Ticket #4045 (Large blogs fatal error in cache.php: extreme memory consumption on ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
The unserialize/serialize was introduced by [4856] and [4857] to fix #3726. The purpose is to remove references inside objects. I can see why it's being done, however this method does eat a ton of memory for large objects.

Perhaps these calls need to be moved closer to the actual problem area and out of the general cache functions entirely?

item.title: widgetpatch.patch attached to Ticket #4671
item.dc:creator: brettz95
item.description: Fix empty <ul> issue in widget.php

item.title: Ticket #4671 (Empty ul in RSS widget when only a title present) created
item.dc:creator: brettz95
item.description: An empty <ul> element is created (and this is not XHTML kosher) when the RSS widget is used and there is only a title present (no items). The patch does a test to see if the array containing $rss->items is empty before adding <ul> tags. Didn't see a version number for this, but I assume its 2.3 as I just downloaded it...

item.title: Changeset [5818]: In your cats, making them back compat.

item.description: In your cats, making them back compat.

item.title: Ticket #4045 (Large blogs fatal error in cache.php: extreme memory consumption on ...) updated
item.dc:creator: torbens
item.description:
By simply commenting out the vicious line 48 of cache.php, I got my blog working again: 

	$data = unserialize(serialize($data));

This line does look pretty weird to me anyway. Anybody an idea what it's supposed to do except for a lot of allocs?
